hints.content:
An $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number is a multiple of $2$. It can be split into $2$ equal groups.
[[☃ image 1]]

$\blueD6$, $\blueD{12}$, $\blueD{20}$, $\blueD{34}$, $\blueD{50}$, $. . .$

options.alt: A 256x256 pixel image showing six vibrant blue circles arranged in two distinct groups of three. Each group of three circles is clearly enclosed by a soft, dashed blue circle, illustrating that an even number can be perfectly divided into two equal halves. The background is clean and white, emphasizing the visual representation of an even number.

hints.content:
An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number is **not** a multiple of $2$. It **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

[[☃ image 1]]

$\maroonD{11}$, $\maroonD{23}$, $\maroonD{35}$, $\maroonD{47}$, $\maroonD{59}$, $. . . $

options.alt: A 256x256 pixel image displaying seven vibrant magenta circles. They are divided into two unequal groups; one group contains three circles, and the other contains four circles. Each group is enclosed by a soft, dashed magenta circle, visually demonstrating that an odd number cannot be perfectly split into two equal parts. The background is clean and white.

hints.content:
$\blueD{\text{even}}$ number $\times$ $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number $=$ $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number 

[[☃ image 1]]

When we multiply by an $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number, we make an $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number of groups.  

So, the product can be split into $2$ equal groups.

The product will always be $\blueD{\text{even}}$.

options.alt: A 256x256 pixel image illustrating an 'Even x Even = Even' multiplication concept. It shows 24 bright blue stars, arranged into six distinct groups. Each group contains four stars. A vertical dashed line divides the total collection into two larger equal halves of three groups each. Each group of four stars is enclosed by a dashed blue circle, clearly demonstrating that the total product can be easily split into two equal halves, thus remaining an even number. The background is simple and white.

hints.content:
$\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number $\times$  $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number $=$ $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number 

[[☃ image 1]]

When we multiply by an $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number, we make an $\blueD{\text{even}}$ number of groups.  

So, the product can be split into $2$ equal groups.

The product will always be $\blueD{\text{even}}$.

options.alt: A 256x256 pixel image demonstrating an 'Odd x Even = Even' multiplication concept. It features 30 vibrant magenta diamonds, organized into six distinct groups. Each group contains five diamonds. A clear vertical dashed line partitions the diamonds into two larger equal halves, with three groups on each side. Each individual group of five diamonds is encircled by a dashed blue line. This visual reinforces that multiplying any number by an even number results in an even product, as the total collection can always be divided equally into two parts. The background is clean and white.

hints.content:
$\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number $\times$ $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number $=$ $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number 

[[☃ image 1]]

When we multiply by an $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number, we make an $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number of groups.  

So, the product **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups.

The product will always be $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$.

options.alt: A 256x256 pixel image illustrating an 'Odd x Odd = Odd' multiplication concept. It displays 15 bright magenta triangles, arranged into five distinct groups. Each group contains three triangles. A horizontal dashed line divides the total collection into two unequal parts: two groups above the line and three groups below it. Each group of three triangles is enclosed by a dashed magenta circle, visually confirming that the total product cannot be evenly split into two equal groups, thus remaining an odd number. The background is clean and white.

hints.content:
The following are true about Leo's numbers:

- Both numbers were odd

question.content:
Leo multiplies two numbers and gets an odd product.  

**Which statement describes the two numbers Leo multiplied?**

[[☃ radio 1]]

choices.alt: A conceptual image showing two even numbers being multiplied, for example, two groups of two objects (total four), which can be divided equally into two groups of two. This results in an even product.

A conceptual image showing two odd numbers being multiplied, for example, three groups of three objects (total nine), which cannot be divided equally into two whole groups. This results in an odd product.

choices.content: One number was even and one was odd
choices.alt: A conceptual image showing an even number multiplied by an odd number, for example, two groups of three objects (total six), which can be divided equally into two groups of three. This results in an even product.
